Award.AwardTitle: Doctoral Dissertation Improvement Award: Ceremonial Organization And Social Structure

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Social, Behav & Economic Scie

Division.LongName: Division Of Behavioral and Cognitive Sci

Award.AbstractNarration:
More than 6000 years ago, small regional polities emerged for the first time in what is now northeastern China. These Hongshan societies represented the early stages in the evolution of forms of organization that integrated the people of different local communities into networks of social, political, and economic relationships. They thus represent the very beginnings of the much larger-scale, highly integrated societies in which most of the world's population now lives. These regional societies were still very small; each including only 1,000 people or so in a territory about 10 km across. Some families clearly enjoyed more social prestige and influence than others, attributable primarily to their special religious and ritual roles. Dozens if not hundreds of such small regional societies were connected with each other through a common focus on a complex of extraordinary ceremonial structures in which very highly prestigious individuals were buried. This complex at Niuheliang seems to have functioned primarily as a religious pilgrimage center, with a relatively small community of permanent residents, who lived in a hilly region with very little agricultural potential. Under the direction of Dr. Robert Drennan, doctoral candidate Weiyu Ran will carry out fieldwork at the nearby Hongshan-period village of Shangchaoyanggou to investigate how the provisioning of this pilgrimage center was organized. Several villages, of which Shangchaoyanggou was one, were located a few kilometers from the ritual facilities of Niuheliang in much more favorable locations for farming and may have specialized in producing food to sustain the nearby pilgrimage center. If this is the kind of organization that had emerged in Hongshan times, it represented a major step toward more highly developed economies and greater interdependence between households and local communities than ever before.

Mr. Ran will evaluate this hypothetical reconstruction of early Hongshan economies and the organization that sustained the pilgrimage center at Niuheliang by collecting data on the cultural remains left behind thousands of years ago by the inhabitants of Shangchaoyanggou. The parts of this refuse that have been preserved for so long are mostly fragments of broken pottery vessels and stone tools. If Shangchaoyanggo focused heavily on agricultural production then the data Mr. Ran collects will show high proportions of agricultural tools and low proportions of the elaborate pottery vessels that signaled social prestige (when compared to the artifacts of ordinary Hongshan communities or to those remaining at residential locations near the most important ritual structures). If this is what the research results show, it will be clear that in at least some instances a very early focus on religion and ritual as a principal means of social integration can lead to the development of the more advanced economic systems upon which even larger-scale political integration eventually was based.

POR.DRECONTENT:
It has been observed that ritual activities often had great importance in the emergence and development of the earliest complex societies, although the roles they played in different developmental trajectories varied considerably. For the Neolithic Hongshan period (4500-3000 BC) in northeastern China, a major pilgrimage center at Niuheliang provided cultural integration across a very large area occupied by scores of small, separate and independent regional polities, each only a few kilometers across and having only 1000 to 2000 inhabitants. Ritual activities provided vital political integration within these polities as well, in the form of ceremonies carried out at specially-constructed platforms, one or two of which characteristically lay at the heart of each small polity.


Under the supervision of Dr. Robert D. Drennan, Ph.D. candidate Weiyu Ran conducted an intensive surface collection across an area of six hectares in the Hongshan-period village site at Shangchaoyanggou, chosen for its proximity to the pilgrimage center at Niuheliang and for its location in a setting much more favorable for agricultural production than the stony hills in which the ceremonial structures of Niuheliang sit. The fieldwork systematically delineated the locations of 41 Hongshan-period household units and a ceremonial platform within this dispersed Neolithic village of 100-200 residents. The surface collections recovered substantial samples of artifacts directly associated with individual households, making it possible to reconstruct their activities in order to compare them with those of other households at Shangchaoyanggou and of households at other previously-studied Hongshan villages.


Very little productive differentiation has been detected at other Hongshan villages, and households at Shangchaoyanggou showed even less economic interdependence than usual. In addition, the prestige differentiation seen between households at other Hongshan villages was comparatively underdeveloped at Shangchaoyanggou. High proportions of agricultural tools at Shangchaoyanggou, however, did indicate a stronger concentration on food production than at other Hongshan villages. At the same time, and despite Shangchaoyanggou's proximity to the remarkable concentration of ceremonial structures at Niuheliang, ritual-related artifacts occurred in surprisingly low proportions at Shangchaoyanggou households. This pattern of activities suggests complementarity between activities at Shangchaoyanggou and Niuheliang, and a degree of interdependence between villages not seen elsewhere in the Hongshan cultural area. A strong focus on food production at Shangchaoyanggou seems instrumental in provsioning a corps of ritual specialists attending to ceremonies and the needs of visitors to Niuheliang's ritual facilities.


This research, then, documents a very early complex society in which ritual differentiation between households and a strong role for ritual and religion in both small-scale political integration and large-scale cultural uniformity stimulated the development of more complex economic arrangements to provide a stable food supply for ritual specialists. This economic development, nonetheless, remained in a literally supporting role in a cultural and political system integrated by religious belief and ritual activity. Accumulation of wealth or other forms of resource control did not appear in Hongshan societies.

As dissertation research, the project provided essential experience in designing and carrying out field research for the doctoral candidate. In addition, six students from Capital Normal University, Minzu University of China and Hunan University participated in the fieldwork and gained training in the methodology of intensive surface collection. Local residents had an opportunity to participate in the archaeological recovery of information about the distant past of their own region.
